blocks.content: Network scanning means examining a network to find active systems, open ports, services, and weaknesses. In naval style, it is like using radar to detect ships in the sea and understand their strength.
Whenever you see the word TARGET IP, we will use the IP provided in the TryHackMe Blue Room lab.
Network discovery helps find which devices are active. This is like detecting all ships present in your sea zone.

content: Why: To check if the target is reachable.
Why: To find active hosts without scanning ports.

blocks.content: Port scanning checks which ports are open. It is like checking which doors on an enemy ship are open, closed, or guarded.

content: Why: To scan all ports on the target.
Why: To scan only important ports.

blocks.content: Version detection tells us what service and version is running on each port. Like identifying the enemy ship’s weapons and communication systems.

content: Why: To find service versions on open ports.
Why: Runs default Nmap scripts for more details.

blocks.content: This helps identify weaknesses in software or services, like spotting weak armor on a ship.

content: Why: To scan for known vulnerabilities.
Why: To check for web server vulnerabilities.
We will use the Blue Room from TryHackMe to practice all scans. Replace TARGET IP with the IP given by the room.
